- **Step 1:** Define the roles and objectives of each country.
- **Step 2:** Use markdown to structure the dialogue format.
- **Step 3:** Ensure natural language flow with appropriate speech patterns.

### 3. Game State Management

**Objective:** Model the game state transitions based on player actions.

```cpp
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>

using namespace std;

struct Country {
    string name;
    string role;
    int status; // 1 for active, -1 for dead
};

vector<Country> createCountryVector(const string& name, const string& role) {
    vector<Country> countries;
    countries.push_back({name, role, 1});
    return countries;
}

int main() {
    // Example game state setup
    int day = 3;
    int night = 3;
    vector<string> players = {"Peter", "Talia", "Enrique"};
    
    // Initialize country states
    vector<Country> currentCountries;
    for (const auto& player : players) {
        if (player == "Sarah") {
            Country country = {"Treasure", "Hero", -1};
            currentCountries.push_back(country);
        } else {
            Country country = {"Country A", "Enemy", 1};
            currentCountries.push_back(country);
        }
    }
    
    // Example dialogue generation
    for (const auto& country : currentCountries) {
        if (country.status == 1) {
            cout << "[*] " << country.name << "'s perspective:\n";
            cout << "> " << country.role << ": 'Hello, I'm " << players[day] << "'\n";
        }
    }
    
    return 0;
}
```

- **Dialogue Generation:** Uses a vector of country structs to represent each nation's perspective, facilitating natural language dialogue generation.
- **Game State Management:** Implements a simplified game state with status tracking and example interactions.

This approach ensures that all components are addressed systematically, providing a clear and maintainable solution.
